head.title: Slain Tourist's Family to Sue New York City

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Slain Tourist's Family to Sue New York City

block.p: The family of Brian Watkins, the Utah tourist slain in a subway mugging last summer, has notified the city that it intends to file a lawsuit seeking $100 million, the Comptroller's office said yesterday.
The notice charges that the city and the Transit Authority, failed to provide "a competent, adequate and safe place for the general riding public" the night Mr. Watkins was killed.
The notice of intent to sue charges that the authority did not properly train its token clerks to respond to emergencies or provide "adequate security devices."
It also charges that the city Emergency Medical Services was negligent in its response and treatment of Mr. Watkins.
Mr. Watkins, 22 years old, of Provo, Utah, was with his family when they were mugged Sept. 2 in a Manhattan subway station by a group of youths.
Mr. Watkins interceded when one youth punched his mother in the face. He was stabbed in the chest and died a short time later. Eight suspects have been charged with murder.
The family's lawyer, Charles S. Brofman, was out of his office yesterday and could not be reached for comment on when the suit would be filed, his secretary said.
They have until December 1991 to file suit.
